title: 108_hr2235
content: The Act may be cited as the "Emergency Immigration Workload Reduction and Homeland Security Enhancement Act of 2003". The table of contents for this Act is provided. The "Emergency Immigration Workload Reduction and Homeland Security Enhancement Act of 2003" includes provisions for the temporary suspension of various visa programs, restrictions on nonimmigrant visas for certain countries, waivers for temporary suspensions, and funding for detention and removal assistance. The Act also includes a severability clause and specifies the effective date of implementation. The Act specifies the effective date as the first Sunday occurring two weeks after enactment. The Congress emphasizes the importance of the Directorate of Border and Transportation Security in carrying out immigration enforcement responsibilities. Certain immigration programs may need to be temporarily suspended to ensure national security interests are not compromised. Certifications from the Secretary of Homeland Security are required for the effective transfer of immigration enforcement functions to the Directorate. Temporary suspension of the Visa Waiver Program is mandated. The Visa Waiver Program, adjustment of status for permanent residence, renewals of Temporary Protected Status, and certain immigrant visa programs are temporarily suspended for national security interests. The Secretary of Homeland Security's authority is affected, including the acceptance of applications for status adjustments. The allocation of family-sponsored immigrant visas to alien relatives of citizens and permanent residents is suspended under the Immigration and Nationality Act for national security interests. The admission of such aliens to the United States as immigrants is also temporarily halted. Children of lawful permanent residents are temporarily suspended from receiving family-sponsored immigrant visas under the Immigration and Nationality Act, except for dependent children under 18 years old. Diversity immigrants are also suspended from receiving immigrant visas. The suspension includes the acceptance of classification petitions for affected immigrant visa categories. SEC. 7. RESTRICTION OF NONIMMIGRANT VISAS FOR NATIONALS OF COUNTRIES DENYING OR DELAYING ACCEPTANCE OF ALIENS. The Secretary of Homeland Security will create a public listing of aliens with final removal orders but no likelihood of removal soon due to countries refusing to accept them. If 24 or more citizens of a foreign state are on this list, that state will be considered as denying or delaying acceptance of these aliens, leading to visa restrictions. Consular officers must stop issuing nonimmigrant visas to citizens of foreign states that refuse to accept aliens with final removal orders. The Secretary of Homeland Security has the authority to waive certain sections on a case-by-case basis or for designated classes of applicants, with concurrence from the Secretary of State. The waiver authority can be delegated to the Secretary of State for specific classes of applicants. The Secretary of Homeland Security can waive certain sections on a case-by-case basis or for designated classes of applicants with the Secretary of State's approval. Sections 3 through 8 will expire one week after the conditions related to entry and exit data systems, machine-readable visas, and removal capabilities are met. The Secretary of Homeland Security has the capability to detain and remove aliens identified by State or local law enforcement agencies. Adequate federal funds are available for reimbursement of claims. The data system for alien registration must comply with integration standards and ensure timely entry of registrations for visa applications. The Secretary of Homeland Security can detain and remove aliens identified by State or local law enforcement. Federal funds are available for reimbursement. The data system for alien registration must comply with integration standards and ensure timely entry of registrations for visa applications. A program for random audits of immigration status change applications by aliens in the US has been implemented. The program indicates that fraud or false statements are no more than 3% of approved applications. The foreign student monitoring system is operational, ensuring no illegal aliens are admitted to educational institutions. The number of aliens removed from the US has increased by at least 25% compared to the previous year. All required reports, plans, and operational transfers under the Homeland Security Act have been successfully executed. The backlog of immigration benefit applications has been eliminated as required by law. The annual report under the American Competitiveness Act has been submitted to Congress, and process changes have been implemented. SEC. 10. SUSPENSION OF NONIMMIGRANT VISAS. The Secretary of State's authority to issue nonimmigrant visas and the Secretary of Homeland Security's authority to admit nonimmigrant aliens into the United States are suspended. This includes the suspension of acceptance for filing of applications for nonimmigrant visas and admission as a nonimmigrant. The Secretary of Homeland Security may waive these suspensions under certain conditions. Aliens admitted on nonimmigrant visas must have a personal interview with a consular officer. Waivers granted for aliens barred from nonimmigrant visas will be superseded by the bar. SEC. 11. TEMPORARY FUNDING FOR DETENTION AND REMOVAL ASSISTANCE BY STATE AND LOCAL LAW ENFORCEMENT AGENCIES. The Secretary of Homeland Security will reimburse law enforcement agencies for emergency medical care, housing, and transportation of detained aliens if certain conditions are met, including transfer to Federal custody and a determination of removability.
